questions.question: What period is known as the 'Gandhian era' in the Indian national movement?
Who led the national movement after the death of Lokmanya Tilak in 1920?
What principles did Mahatma Gandhi give to the freedom movement?
Why did Mahatma Gandhi go to South Africa in 1893?
How were Indians treated in South Africa?
questions.answer: They were treated as criminals and humiliated.

questions.question: What did the South African government declare in 1906?
questions.answer: That it was compulsory for blacks to carry an identity card and their freedom was restricted.

questions.question: What did Gandhiji do in response to the injustice in South Africa?
questions.answer: He followed the path of Satyagraha and gained justice for the people.

questions.question: When did Gandhiji return to India from South Africa?
Who suggested that Gandhiji tour the entire nation?
Where did Gandhiji stay in Ahmedabad?
What does Satyagraha mean?
What is the main objective of Satyagraha?
questions.answer: To make an unjust person aware of truth and justice through patience and non-violence.

questions.question: Who was influenced by Gandhiji's Satyagraha in America?
Who was influenced by Gandhiji's Satyagraha in South Africa?
What was the Champaran Satyagraha about?
questions.answer: Farmers in Bihar were forced to cultivate indigo and were exploited economically.

questions.question: When did Gandhiji go to Champaran?
What was the outcome of the Champaran Satyagraha?
questions.answer: It was successful and the farmers were given justice.

questions.question: Why did the farmers of Kheda start a movement?
questions.answer: Due to crop failure from famine, yet the government forcibly collected land tax.

questions.question: What did Gandhiji suggest to the Kheda farmers?
questions.answer: To refuse to pay the tax.

questions.question: What was the result of the Kheda Satyagraha?
What caused the workers' movement in Ahmedabad?
questions.answer: Inflation during WWI; mill workers demanded a salary rise which was rejected.

questions.question: What did the Ahmedabad workers do as per Gandhiji's advice?
questions.answer: They went on a hunger strike.

questions.question: What was the Rowlatt Act?
questions.answer: A law passed in 1919 allowing arrest without warrant and imprisonment without trial.

questions.question: Why was the Rowlatt Act called the 'Black Act'?
questions.answer: Because it gave arbitrary powers to the government and denied civil rights.

questions.question: When did Gandhiji launch Satyagraha against the Rowlatt Act?
What happened on 13th April 1919 in Amritsar?
questions.answer: The Jallianwala Bagh massacre took place.

questions.question: Who ordered the firing at Jallianwala Bagh?
How many rounds were fired at Jallianwala Bagh?
How many people were killed in the Jallianwala Bagh massacre?
What did Rabindranath Tagore do in protest of the massacre?
questions.answer: He returned his 'Sir' title bestowed by the British.

questions.question: What was the Khilafat Movement?
questions.answer: A movement by Indian Muslims to support the Khalifa (Turkish ruler) after WWI.

questions.question: Why did Gandhiji support the Khilafat Movement?
questions.answer: To unite Hindus and Muslims in a national movement.

questions.question: What was the concept behind the Non-cooperation Movement?
questions.answer: That British rule depended on Indian cooperation, and complete non-cooperation would collapse it.

questions.question: Where was the Congress session held in 1920 that accepted the Non-cooperation resolution?
Who proposed the Non-cooperation resolution?
What did the Non-cooperation programme include?
questions.answer: Boycott of government offices, courts, foreign goods, and government schools/colleges.

questions.question: Which lawyers boycotted courts during the Non-cooperation Movement?
questions.answer: Motilal Nehru, Chittaranjan Das, and others.

questions.question: What was established as part of the national education scheme?
How was the Prince of Wales welcomed in 1921?
questions.answer: With hartals, lonely roads, and closed shops.

questions.question: What incident caused Gandhiji to suspend the Non-cooperation Movement?
questions.answer: The Chauri Chaura incident in February 1922, where a police station was burnt and policemen were killed.

questions.question: When did Gandhiji suspend the Non-cooperation Movement?
What was the Mulshi Satyagraha?
questions.answer: A satyagraha by farmers in Mulshi Taluka, Pune, against the government during the Non-cooperation Movement.

questions.question: Who led the Mulshi Satyagraha?
Why was Gandhiji arrested in March 1922?
questions.answer: For writing three anti-national articles in 'Young India'.

questions.question: What was Gandhiji's sentence in 1922?
What were Gandhiji's constructive programmes?
questions.answer: Spread of Swadeshi, Hindu-Muslim unity, prohibition of alcohol, removal of untouchability, use of Khadi, and national education.

questions.question: Who established the Swaraj Party?
When was the Swaraj Party established?
What was the aim of the Swaraj Party?
questions.answer: To contest elections and obstruct the British government's work.

questions.question: Who was appointed as the chairman of the Simon Commission?
Why was the Simon Commission boycotted?
questions.answer: Because it had no Indian members.

questions.question: What slogan was raised against the Simon Commission?
Who died after being attacked during a protest against the Simon Commission?
What did Lala Lajpat Rai say after being attacked?
questions.answer: “Every blow on my body will prove a nail in the coffin of the British Empire.”

questions.question: Who was the chairman of the committee that drafted the Nehru Report?
What did the Nehru Report propose?
questions.answer: Self-government for India, adult franchise, and linguistic division of provinces.

questions.question: What was the outcome if the Nehru Report was not accepted?
questions.answer: Civil Disobedience Movement would be started.

questions.question: Where was the Congress session held in December 1929?
Who presided over the Lahore session of 1929?
What resolution was passed in the Lahore session?
questions.answer: The resolution for complete independence (Poorna Swaraj).

questions.question: What did the Congress give up in the Lahore session?
On which date was the tricolor flag unfurled by Pandit Nehru?
Which date was declared as Independence Day?
What pledge did people take on 26th January 1930?
questions.answer: To carry out the freedom movement with non-violent means for India's independence.

questions.question: What was the Hunter Commission appointed for?
questions.answer: To enquire into the Jallianwala Bagh massacre.

questions.question: Why did Gandhiji start the Non-cooperation Movement?
questions.answer: To collapse British rule by withdrawing Indian cooperation.

questions.question: What was the impact of foreign cloth boycott?
questions.answer: Import of foreign clothes decreased significantly.

questions.question: Who were the young leaders demanding complete independence?
questions.answer: Pandit Nehru and Subhash Chandra Bose.

questions.question: What was the main demand of the Khilafat Movement?
questions.answer: To protect the Khalifa's empire and rights of Muslims.

questions.question: What was the role of the Swaraj Party in legislatures?
questions.answer: They opposed unjust British policies and demanded responsible government.

questions.question: What was the significance of the Nagpur session of 1920?
questions.answer: It officially launched the Non-cooperation Movement under Gandhi's leadership.

questions.question: What did Gandhiji do after suspending the Non-cooperation Movement?
questions.answer: He focused on constructive programmes like Khadi, untouchability removal, etc.

questions.question: What was the British response to the Non-cooperation Movement?
questions.answer: They undertook repressive measures to control it.

questions.question: What was the role of students in the Non-cooperation Movement?
questions.answer: They boycotted government schools and joined national institutions.

questions.question: What was the impact of the Non-cooperation Movement in rural areas?
questions.answer: It became more comprehensive through constructive programmes.

questions.question: Why was the Montague-Chelmsford Act unsatisfactory?
questions.answer: It did not grant responsible government and retained key powers with the British.

questions.question: Who was Michael O'Dwyer?
questions.answer: The Governor of Punjab during the Jallianwala Bagh massacre.

questions.question: What was the significance of 26th January 1930?
questions.answer: It was celebrated as Independence Day with pledges for freedom.

questions.question: What did Gandhiji mean by 'Swaraj'?
What was the role of women in the Non-cooperation Movement?
questions.answer: They participated in protests, promoted Khadi, and joined national education.

questions.question: What was the Chauri Chaura incident?
questions.answer: A violent incident where a police station was burnt, leading to deaths of policemen.

questions.question: How did the British try to suppress the Rowlatt Act protests?
questions.answer: Through arrests, bans, and eventually the Jallianwala Bagh massacre.

questions.question: What was the role of the press during the Non-cooperation Movement?
questions.answer: It spread nationalist ideas and reported on protests and repression.

questions.question: What was the difference between Dominion Status and Poorna Swaraj?
questions.answer: Dominion Status meant self-governance under British crown; Poorna Swaraj meant complete independence.

questions.question: What was the impact of the Khilafat Movement on Hindu-Muslim unity?
questions.answer: It temporarily strengthened Hindu-Muslim unity during the Non-cooperation Movement.

questions.question: What was Gandhiji's approach to fighting injustice?
questions.answer: Through non-violent Satyagraha and civil disobedience.

questions.question: What was the British strategy to counter the Non-cooperation Movement?
questions.answer: Repression, arrests, and attempts to divide communities.

questions.question: What was the role of peasants in the Non-cooperation Movement?
questions.answer: They participated in no-tax campaigns and satyagrahas like in Kheda and Mulshi.

questions.question: What was the significance of the flag unfurling on 31st December 1929?
questions.answer: It symbolized the commitment to Poorna Swaraj and independence.

questions.question: What was the role of the Swaraj Party after the Non-cooperation Movement?
questions.answer: It continued the struggle through legislative means and opposition in councils.

questions.question: Why was the Nehru Report significant?
questions.answer: It was the first major Indian attempt to draft a constitution for self-rule.

questions.question: What was the British reaction to the Lahore Congress resolution?
questions.answer: They ignored the demand for Poorna Swaraj, leading to the Civil Disobedience Movement.

questions.question: What was the role of Motilal Nehru in the freedom movement?
questions.answer: He was a prominent leader of the Swaraj Party and chaired the Nehru Report committee.

questions.question: What was the impact of the Non-cooperation Movement on British authority?
questions.answer: It challenged British legitimacy and mobilized masses on a large scale.

questions.question: What was the role of Subhash Chandra Bose in the demand for Poorna Swaraj?
questions.answer: He was a strong advocate for complete independence alongside Nehru.

questions.question: What was the condition of Indians in South Africa that motivated Gandhiji?
questions.answer: Racial discrimination, humiliation, and restrictive laws like the identity card rule.

questions.question: What was the importance of the Sabarmati Ashram?
questions.answer: It served as a center for planning and launching Gandhiji's satyagrahas and movements.

questions.question: What was the role of Chittaranjan Das in the Non-cooperation Movement?
questions.answer: He proposed the Non-cooperation resolution and later co-founded the Swaraj Party.

questions.question: What was the impact of the Jallianwala Bagh massacre on the national movement?
questions.answer: It intensified anger against British rule and united Indians in protest.

questions.question: What was the ultimate goal of the Non-cooperation Movement?
questions.answer: To achieve Swaraj (self-rule) through non-violent non-cooperation with the British.
